author: Jardel Barros
title: Social project for digital inclusio
description: Many people around the world do not have access to the internet or computers

assessments.note:
While digital inclusion is certainly important (the Africa special had many good examples), giving people access to the internet and computers will not necessarily grow the Cardano ecosystem without specific purpose. Do you expect people who were presumably technology illiterate to have an interest in the Cardano community and making meaningful contributions? I do not see the connection.

As the target group is people that are excluded from society, you can not access these in schools (this is were funds could actually go to and have a program on Internet/Blockchain use).

The idea is good, but to jump from learning about computer and internet into the blockchain world might be very challenging. I believe a better challenge setting would be to enhance the digital inclusion in places where technology has not reached yet, for example, and link use this to make publicity for Cardano as an sponsor of digital inclusion. It would be worth it to check what is happening in Cardano Africa initiatives.

In general, this could be, if implemented correctly, an important measure to increase social digital inclusion in general and to some amount the interest and inclusion in Cardano. It needs to be minded that the measures are properly integrated and adapted to the people need and actuall access to devices and internet is considered.
Blockchain needs people connected to technology/computers/internet yes but the execution plan is lacking and requires many more details on how to accomplish.

The challenge presented is undoubtedly a very big issue for a large part of the global population. How could we expect the disenfranchised and the unbanked to participate in the revolution and the coming new age when they do not yet have the basic knowledge of computers and electronic tools and how they work. There is merit in pursuing solutions in this particular challenge. They would primarily need to be hands-on, face-to-face programs which would also be localised in different geographical areas around the world.

Increasing digital inclusion is a great mission, that aligns perfectly with the Cardano mission of empowering people in developing countries. 
Unfortunately the proposal for a challenge itself is not very well framed and might deter voters, it has a very brief explanation on why this is important and seems to focus on Brazil
Whilst the idea may be great, it lacks detail and is probably wider than Cardano's goals.

While it is unfortunate that people all over the world have none or limited access to online content, Cardano's mission is to bank the unbanked, primary demographic target being within the African continent. This proposed challenge setting appears to be outside of those parameters and therefore not critical to achieve the current mission.

There is no challenge question. A statement was included in place of the challenge question, I recommend the modification for clarity of purpose.

Digital inclusion is a relevant aspect of Cardano's mission, but the rationale for this challenge needs further refinement to make it clearer what kind of proposals can arise from it.

Digital inclusion is a brilliant objective and Cardano's initiatives in Africa show how serious the community is about that. I think the idea here may be better suited to a specific proposal rather than a category of challenge however, as there are many agencies trying to encourage digital inclusion and we need to focus on things that will develop Cardano and its use across existing networks so that it can be adopted widely, including in areas lacking in digital inclusion.
I believe that the community has people who can teach people in Brazil how a computer works.

The challenge would need most hardware than software to be executed. To bring people that are not already connected to the internet into the blockchain world would be very challenging. Regarding the digital inclusion side only, it would be more feasible.
Assuming there is a sufficient amount of Portugese speaking people within the community and some locals, it should have the potential to adress this challenge

Anyone can help each other in learning about computers, I think the community does that anyway because they are interested in what can be done with blockchain and want to share that with the world. Its not clear what this proposal is needing exactly.

The Cardano Community is spread globally. And inherent in our belief in Cardano is the spirit of adventure, of sharing and of entrepreneurship. Why else would we invest in a project which started on a whiteboard and for many years had no functional product? Because of this, the challenge presented here will be taken up by quite a number of ADA believers, including those who may not have been planning on putting through Catalyst proposals under the challenges we've focussed on so far. Most of us are too far removed from the African continent and could only help from afar by donations, etc. This challenge provides a number of us to assist locally and at the same time propagate Cardano to the uninitiated. I am very sure even those of us who live in the western world are aware of segments of our local populations who have not been lucky enough to have access to 21st century tools. I say bring it on!

We have already seen proposals in previous funds that would align with this challenge and the catalyst community is spread across a wide geographical area with many opportunities for impactfull proposals to be generated
This seems too big a goal for the cardano community.

At the moment Cardano is still very early in its grand scheme and we are yet to see its effect on the poverty levels of developing countries. Perhaps with more time and data, it will be possible to determine if certain success can be replicated in other regions of the world.

it is difficult to understand what kind of proposals can arise from this challenge, in addition, restricting the successful of this challenge to the Brazilian community greatly limits the possibilities of proposals that can arise.

Digital inclusion is a much bigger problem in Africa than in Brazil, why limit this challenge to one region?

In Brazil 74% of the population has access to the internet (https://valor.globo.com/empresas/noticia/2020/05/26/acesso-a-internet-cresce-no-brasil-mas-28percent-dos-domicilios -noo-are-connected.ghtml)

Looking at data from Africa, the numbers appear to be worse (https://www.pewresearch.org/global/2018/10/09/internet-use-is-growing-across-much-of-sub-saharan-africa- but-most-are-still-offline /)

Development goals such as digital inclusion can be encouraged by Cardano and enabled by specific projects such as seen championed by IOHK in Africa, and their plan is to roll them out around the world. I am not sure that a further challenge to the Catalyst community in this regard is the best way forward at this time.

The challenge setting mentions some project metrics that could be used to evaluate the challenge's success, but metric for the proposals themselves are missing. KPIs such as number of people involved and local communities reached are examples of good metrics for this challenge.
The metrics set are a bit unclear and difficult to determine. Especially in the respect of how they will be quantified. In general the metrics could be more detailed and diversified.

Metrics would be nice. How many teaching hours would the budget cover? Where would be the targeted audience? How much does it cost to teach per hour? How many people would learn? There are so many questions here, it would be beneficial to narrow the scope of this proposal by a significant amount. Start with a clear understanding of who will learn from this and when/how that will occur. An itinerary of the material would be great.

The metrics provided by this succinct proposal is not as expansive as other metrics presented. However it contains the gist of what and who this challenge will help and can easily be expanded upon by the community as a whole. That said, if additional time is available to the proposer, it is recommended that a more in depth response is provided so that voters get a sense of confidence and push this challenge forward.

Success criteria and metric to measure are not well set and seem to focus on Brazil. Relevant metrics could be, 1) number of people that gained access to a computer or internet, 2) number of people trained in some IT skill
The challenge idea needs detailed goals and associated metrics.

The proposer provided limited amount of KPIs and performance metrics necessary to track the performance of this challenge setting. They are encouraged to expand upon their idea and align it better with the current Cardano's roadmap.

Only two success metrics have been included, both are subjective and would not be good indicators for verifying progress. The definition of success is subjective and restricts the challenge to proposals that address only the Brazilian community.

Sustainability and  social impact of particular solutions would definitely need to be assessed as criteria for any projects in this area. More detailed metrics as to what would encourage theses aspects, and other details as to background of proponents, their capability, commitment, contacts and ability to achieve goals would I think also need to be requested and meaasured.

importance: bring projects that impact the real life of the people who need it most and who are excluded from society.
